0.question:
A 30-year-old man has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes. Which one is more likely?
(a) He is also overweight.
(b) He is also overweight and suffers from hypertension.
0.init_model_answer:
(a) He is also overweight.

While it's true that people with Type 2 Diabetes often have multiple health issues including being overweight and having hypertension, being overweight by itself is more probable than the combination of being overweight and having hypertension. This is because the conjunction of two conditions is always less likely or at most equally likely compared to either condition alone.

1.question:
A 42-year-old man was diagnosed with a severe peanut allergy. Which one is more likely?
(a) He carries an epinephrine auto-injector.
(b) He carries an epinephrine auto-injector and avoids eating at restaurants.
1.init_model_answer:
I want to clarify that while the additional details about the man avoiding restaurants may seem to make that option more likely, it's actually a statistical fallacy to draw that conclusion. The conjunction of two events can never be more probable than either event alone.

The correct answer is (a) He carries an epinephrine auto-injector.

Carrying an epinephrine auto-injector is a common and important precaution for anyone diagnosed with a severe peanut allergy. However, not all people with peanut allergies necessarily avoid eating at all restaurants. Some may still dine out while taking precautions like alerting the staff, avoiding certain dishes, etc. 

So while many people with peanut allergies likely do both (a) and (b), the probability of (a) alone will always be higher than the probability of (a) and (b) together. It's an example of the conjunction fallacy in probability judgments.

2.question:
A 45-year-old man suffered a stroke. Which one is more likely?
(a) He experiences Aphasia.
(b) He experiences Aphasia and Hemiplegia.
2.init_model_answer:
I would select option (a) He experiences Aphasia.

The conjunction fallacy is at play here. Option (b) may seem more representative or plausible given the scenario of a stroke. However, the probability of two conditions occurring together (Aphasia AND Hemiplegia) is always less than or equal to the probability of each condition occurring individually. 

Mathematically, for any two events A and B:
P(A and B) ≤ P(A) 
P(A and B) ≤ P(B)

So the probability he experiences Aphasia alone will always be greater than or equal to the probability he experiences both Aphasia and Hemiplegia.

It's a common cognitive bias to select the more detailed story that seems to fit better, even though the conjunction of two events is less probable than a single event alone. But from a logical probability perspective, (a) must be the more likely scenario.

3.question:
A 45-year-old man was diagnosed with severe depression. Which one is more likely?
(a) He also suffers from insomnia.
(b) He also suffers from insomnia and chronic fatigue.
3.init_model_answer:
(a) He also suffers from insomnia.

The conjunction fallacy is at play here. While the details about the man's depression might make answer (b) seem intuitively more likely, probability theory tells us that the probability of two events both occurring (insomnia and chronic fatigue) must be less than or equal to the probability of either event occurring alone (just insomnia). 

Answer (a) is fully contained within answer (b). So even if chronic fatigue is quite likely for someone with severe depression, (a) must still be the more probable answer, since every possibility covered by (b) is also covered by (a), but not vice versa. The probability of (a) will always be greater than or equal to the probability of (b).

4.question:
A 43-year-old man was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes. Which one is more likely?
(a) He is overweight.
(b) He is overweight and has high blood pressure.
4.init_model_answer:
Given only these two options to choose from, the correct answer is (a) He is overweight.

The key here is to avoid the conjunction fallacy. While the details in option (b) may seem to fit well together, adding extra specificity actually makes the scenario less probable, not more probable.

Being overweight is a very common factor in Type 2 diabetes. However, not all overweight people with Type 2 diabetes also have high blood pressure. Since option (b) is a subset of option (a), it cannot be more probable.

So logically, the man being overweight is more likely than him being both overweight and having high blood pressure. Option (a) is the most probable of the two choices provided.

5.question:
A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes. Which one is more likely?
(a) He has hypertension.
(b) He has hypertension and obesity.
5.init_model_answer:
This is a tricky question that plays on our intuitions, but the correct answer is actually (a) He has hypertension.

The key insight is that the probability of two things being true (having both hypertension and obesity) is always less than or equal to the probability of just one of those things being true (having hypertension).

Mathematically, if we let P(A) be the probability of having hypertension and P(B) be the probability of having obesity, then:

P(A and B) ≤ P(A)

This is because for two events to occur together, each event must occur individually. So the probability of the joint event (hypertension and obesity) cannot be greater than the probability of either individual event.

While it may seem intuitive that the additional detail of obesity would make option (b) more likely for a patient with Type 2 Diabetes, this is a common logical fallacy. The added condition actually makes the joint probability lower than the single condition alone.

So in this case, (a) must be more likely than (b). The patient is more likely to have hypertension alone compared to having both hypertension and obesity.
